reporting_cycle: The Secretary-General reports three months from the date of the adoption of this resolution
summary:
The Security Council,
Recalling all its relevant resolutions, particularly resolution 1582, welcomes the Secretary-General's report and the conclusions of the Lisbon and Istanbul summits of the OSCE regarding Abkhazia, Georgia. 
The Council deplores that the perpetrators of the 2001 shooting down of a UNOMIG helicopter, killing nine people, have not been identified. 
It stresses that the lack of progress on key issues of a comprehensive settlement of the conflict in Abkhazia, Georgia, is unacceptable. 
The Council welcomes the positive momentum given to the UN-led peace process by high-level meetings of the Group of Friends in Geneva and Georgian-Russian summit meetings. 
It reaffirms the commitment of all Member States to Georgia's sovereignty, independence, and territorial integrity within its internationally recognized borders. 
The Council commends and supports the Secretary-General's efforts, with the assistance of the Russian Federation, the Group of Friends, and the OSCE, to promote stabilization and a comprehensive political settlement. 
The Council supports the "Basic Principles for the Distribution of Competences between Tbilisi and Sukhumi" and urges the Abkhaz side to receive and consider the document. 
It calls on both sides to participate in constructive negotiations towards a political settlement, to spare no efforts to overcome mutual mistrust, and to refrain from militant rhetoric and support for military options. 
The Council reminds all concerned to refrain from actions that might impede the peace process and welcomes the convening of regular meetings of senior representatives of the Group of Friends and the United Nations in Geneva. 
It urges the parties to participate actively in task forces and working groups, established to address economic cooperation, return of internally displaced persons and refugees, and political and security matters. 
The Council regrets the cancellation of a meeting on security guarantees planned for July 2005 and expects that such a meeting with full participation of both sides will be held as soon as possible.
